Introduction.Background: The United Kingdom transferred these uninhabited, barren, sub-Antarctic islands to Australia in 1947. Populated by large numbers of seal and bird species, the islands have been designated a nature preserve.

Geography.Location: islands in the Indian Ocean, about two-thirds of the way from Madagascar to Antarctica
Geography.Area - comparative: slightly more than two times the size of Washington, DC
Geography.Terrain: Heard Island - 80% ice-covered, bleak and mountainous, dominated by a large massif (Big Ben) and an active volcano (Mawson Peak); McDonald Islands - small and rocky

Elevation extremes.highest point: Mawson Peak on Big Ben volcano 2,745 m

Geography.Natural hazards: Mawson Peak, an active volcano, is on Heard Island
Geography.Geography - note: Mawson Peak on Heard Island is the highest Australian mountain (at 2,745 meters, it is taller than Mt. Kosciuszko in Australia proper), and one of only two active volcanoes located in Australian territory, the other being McDonald Island; in 1992, McDonald Island broke its dormancy and began erupting; it has erupted several times since, most recently in 2005

Government.Dependency status: territory of Australia; administered from Canberra by the Department of Sustainability, Environment, Water, Population and Communities (Australian Antarctic Division)
Government.Legal system: the laws of Australia, where applicable, apply
Government.Flag description: the flag of Australia is used

Country name.conventional long form: Territory of Heard Island and McDonald Islands

Economy.Economy - overview: The islands have no indigenous economic activity, but the Australian Government allows limited fishing in the surrounding waters. Visits to Heard Island typically focus on terrestrial and marine research and infrequent private expeditions.

Military.Military - note: defense is the responsibility of Australia; Australia conducts fisheries patrols
